title: ●● Gibbon next describes the Great Schism, when, from 1378–1417, there were no fewer than three rival popes. (Confusingly, the term “Great Schism” can also refer to an earlier dispute, between the Eastern and Western branches of Christianity
●● In 1417, the Council of Constance finally sorted things out, and a worthy Roman was accepted by everyone as
Rome accepted with joy and obedience

container-title: in conjunction with Edward Gibbon: Luminous Historian. Richly detailed but somewhat slow going. It takes up the Decline and Fall in detail
title: Young Edward Gibbon: Gentleman of Letters
The standard biography
Edward Gibbon: Luminous Historian
Gibbon and His World
Brief, engaging account, with excellent illustrations
Brisk and engaging, with many striking insights
Gibbon
Concise and lively, the most readable introduction to Gibbon’s life
Gibbon
A really excellent short introduction
The Inward World of the Historian
Imaginative attempt to relate Gibbon’s character and experiences to his history
The Empire Unpossess’d: An Essay on Gibbon’s Decline and Fall
Psychological study, psychoanalytic in emphasis, with valuable insights into preoccupations that underlie the narrative
Gibbon and His Roman Empire
Important pioneering overview of the intellectual context of the Decline and Fall. Still readable and enlightening
SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome
The ideal introduction to Roman history, from the earliest beginnings to the end of the 2nd century A.D., by a leading scholar with long experience at communicating with a general audience
Julian the Apostate
Impressive demonstration of how much can be deduced from ambiguous sources

note: e.g., Agriculture, Iconoclasm, Martyrs, Ostrogoths, and Nudity).
title: Late Antiquity: A Guide to the Postclassical World

Rich and wide-ranging collection of essays by experts. Large-scale discussions of such topics as “Barbarians and Ethnicity” and “War and Violence,” followed by nearly 500 pages of shorter discussions of important individuals and many other relevant topics
The Body and Society: Men, Women, and Sexual Renunciation in Early Christianity
A powerful and sympathetic account of the reasons why early Christianity was drawn to asceticism

note: in which civilization evolved after the centralized Empire broke down.
title: The Rise of Western Christendom: Triumph and Diversity, A.D. 200–1000
Superb overview of the regions, formerly considered barbarous by the Romans
The Mediterranean World in Late Antiquity, A.D. 395–700
An authoritative and readable overview of current debates about ancient culture and its changes
Pagans and Christians
A massive, detailed, and very readable account of religious attitudes in the 2nd and 3rd centuries A.D
The Climax of Rome
A readable and comprehensive overview, from the death of Marcus Aurelius to the death of Constantine, in a “History of Civilization” series

note: Big, superbly illustrated volume with concise essays on various topics (politics, the economy, education, etc.).
title: Panorama of the Classical World
The Fall of Rome and the End of Civilization
A brief, well-illustrated, invigorating rebuttal of claims that the Empire gradually mutated rather than fell, making impressive use of recent archaeological evidence
Framing the Early Middle Ages: Europe and the Mediterranean, 400–800

A monumental, massively detailed study of political and economic Books That Matter: The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire • 213 development; the leading statement of the gradualist view that Heather and Ward-Perkins argue against
Diocletian and the Roman Recovery
Concise overview of this important historical moment

note: Splendidly illustrated, with an emphasis on cultural history.
title: Cambridge Illustrated History of the Roman World
The Byzantines
Not a formal history, but a well-informed account of Byzantine culture as it was experienced from inside

note: concise and readable (originally given as lectures).
title: Pagan and Christian in an Age of Anxiety
Classic study of the crisis of the 3rd century from a psychological point of view
The Turks in World History
The story of the pre-Islamic Turks, their conversion to Islam, and the empire of the Seljuks
Byzantium: The Surprising Life of a Medieval Empire
Stresses the achievements of Byzantine culture, with only brief accounts of historical events
The Formation of Christendom
Especially good on the gradual divergence of the Eastern and Western branches of Christianity
Books That Matter: The History of the Decline and Fall of the
The End of Ancient Christianity
A lucid account of changing attitudes after Christianity became the official religion of the Empire
The History of the Crusades
The classic account
